subject: Re: Lexical sets in groups
msgSnippet: ... Et/Ate, It/Eat, and Foot/Ooze may indeed be neutralized before Roe. But are they neutralized before Utter? Since non-rhotic speakers will make frequent
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
<freeman@...> wrote:
>
> I hadn't realized that you were linking these choices. Putting your
> proposal in columns (this may require a monospace font to look OK):
>
> Set Choice 1 Choice 2
> SQUARE Et + Roe Eight + Roe
> NEAR It + Roe Eat + Roe
> CURE Foot + Roe Ooze + Roe
>


Et/Ate, It/Eat, and Foot/Ooze may indeed be neutralized before Roe.
But are they neutralized before Utter? Since non-rhotic speakers will
make frequent mistake writing Utter for Roe, we should (if possible)
choose a set that makes these mistakes more readable.

Choosing one of It/Eat + Roe may not be so straight forward. #26It and
Eat are overloaded: they are not just phonemes but (sometimes) stress
indicators with #26It being an unstressed Eat.

I notice, incidentally, that there is objection to ever using #26It
as an unstressed #Eat. Yet there is no objection to using #26It for
unstressed Utter for accents that merge COMMA with KIT. This is not
logically consistent: if Americans will use Eat when unstressed then
New Zealanders will use Utter for the KIT lexical set.
